title: Tuesday, 7th February, 2017

PM11:03am

Cos I was reading this http://www.cftc.go...Releases/pr7528-17

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Which came out late yesterday

PM11:03am

It seems lots of people missed it

PM11:03am

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) today issued an Order filing and settling charges against Forex Capital Markets, LLC (FXCM) , its parent company, FXCM Holdings, LLC (FXCM Holdings), and two founding partners, Dror (“Drew”) Niv, and William Ahdout, who were, respectively, Chief Executive Officer of FXCM and Managing Director of FXCM, (collectively, Respondents). FXCM’s principal place of business is New York, New York; Niv resides in Connecticut; and Ahdout resides in New York.

The CFTC Order finds that, between September 4, 2009 though at least 2014 (the Relevant Period), FXCM engaged in false and misleading solicitations of FXCM’s retail foreign exchange (forex) customers by concealing its relationship with its most important market maker and by misrepresenting that its “No Dealing Desk” platform had no conflicts of interest with its customers. The Order finds FXCM, FXCM Holdings, and Niv responsible for FXCM making false statements to the National Futures Association (NFA) about its relationship with the market maker.

PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-99d3-4dbbb655eda2

PM11:04am

US regulators have punished retail currencies trader FXCM for using algorithms to trade against its own clients, in another stinging blow for global watchdogs against aggressive tactics in the mom-and-pop trading industry.

New York-based FCXM has scrapped its US business and agreed to sell its accounts to one-time rival Gain Capital after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission banned two of the company’s founders from the financial services industry and fined them and the company $7m for defrauding customers.

BE11:14am

Well, yes. Note though that the cashflow miss is accelerated Macondo payments, which the scribblers didn't seem to put into their figures.

BE11:15am

(@St Andrean: nope. Clean is clean.)

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Here's BMO's take.

BE11:16am

New portfolio additions will see BP needing at least $60/bbl, excluding Macondo payments, to balance its cash sources and uses break-even in 2017. Longer term, the new projects such as Zohr, ADCO and Mauritania-Senegal will deliver greater value and cash flows. Near term, BP expects to stay below the top end of its organic capex guidance of $16-17bn.

BE11:16am

Missing on the quarter... 4Q underlying net income of $400m missed consensus expectations of $560m largely due to downstream weakness, driven by a weaker refining environment as well as the impact of a major turnaround at Whiting and weak supply and trading performance. Margins are expected to remain weak in 1Q17; however, lower turnaround activity is expected.
Organic sources & uses balance increase to $60/bbl. BP expects to stay at the higher end of its previous organic capex guidance of $16-17bn in 2017 and achieve disposals in the order of $4.5-5.5bn, more than double our current forecast expectations of $2bn. The increase in the balancing oil price, from $55/bbl, is due to the addition of new projects in late 2017 that require additional cash outflows in their earlier years, such as Mauritania-Senegal.
Delivering a handful of new projects in 2017. On the path to adding 800,000 boepd of new production by 2020, BP confirms it will be starting up new projects this year, including Quad 204, Juniper, Persephone, Khazzan Phase 1 and the Trinidad Onshore Compression project. Thunder Horse South Expansion recently started up ahead of schedule. We fear the Clair delivery will potentially slip into 2018.
Further acquisitions might lie ahead: We expect BP to undertake further acquisitions to rebuild its post-2020 portfolio. Signalling its need to continue to re-build its portfolio, during 4Q, BP entered Zohr (10-15%), ADCO (10%), Mauritania-Senegal (~62/ 32.5% and operatorship) and service stations in Australia.
We reiterate our Market Perform rating and 530p target price. BP trades on 14.8x P/E and 6.3x EV/DACF in 2018E, which are at a discount to the global majors' averages. BP continues to offer a healthy cash plus scrip dividend yield of 6.75%.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And ......... Barclays.

BE11:17am

The 4Q results and outlook for 2017 from BP are somewhat disappointing. Earnings of $400m fell close to 30% short of company-compiled consensus estimates and although there were positives to be taken from a strong upstream performance, this was more than offset by a weaker downstream and a seasonally higher corporate charge. At the same time reflecting additional capex associated with the acquisitions in December the break-even point to cover capex and dividends by the end of 2017 is increased to $60/bl from what had previously been $50-55/bl. Whilst we had recognized that there would be additional spending associated we had hoped that they could be offset by higher cost savings and efficiency gains elsewhere in the business; we would expect more guidance on the call as to how much value these acquisitions will actually add. There is much to commend the investment case for BP as we move into 2017. Eight new projects are due on-stream, and it is clear that the costs savings programme is yielding results. Yet with the signal of a higher break-even price and more details not likely to be available until the strategy update on February 28 and lower than anticipated near term earnings we expect the release to have negative implications for the share price near term. We rate the stock Overweight with a 625p price target.

BE11:22am

BP reported clean net income of $400m (below cons
$560m) and operating profit $856m (cons. $1,170m). The company missed in Downstream, OBC and delivered a lower Rosneft contribution. Important highlights regarding 2017 outlook include: 1) 2017 capex moves into upper half of prior guidance range ($16-17bn; JPMe: $15bn) reflecting end 2016 transactions (most meaningful contributions are ADCO and Mauritania). We think the M&A effect on capex is more front end loaded and continue to expect medium term capex to fall – we expect this to be disclosed with the CMD on 28th Feb (JPMe 2020 capex: $13bn); 2) A partial offset to revised capex guidance is higher divestments. BP has guided to $4.5-5.5bn (previously normalizing to $2-3bn pa from this year); 3) Macondo payments continue to accelerate (94% complete by end 2016); 4) The interim dividend is unchanged at 10c; 5) Gearing (ND/CE) at end 2016 stood at 27% vs. JPMe 28% and 26% at end 3Q.

PM11:24am

I ask because of this piece of Bloomberg clickbait

11:23 am
PM11:24am

‘Death Spiral’ Looms for Zimbabwe Economy as Cash Runs Out

PM11:24am

https://www.bloomb...y-as-cash-runs-out

PM11:24am

Zimbabwe abandoned its own currency eight years ago and adopted mainly the dollar, initially halting hyperinflation. Now, with a floundering economy and a strong dollar stoking imports and curtailing exports, banknotes have virtually disappeared, prompting the central bank to order private lenders to cap customer cash withdrawals at $150 a week. While the Reserve Bank estimates about $4 billion is circulating in the economy, Confederation of Zimbabwe Industries President Busisa Moyo says the amount may be as little as $100 million.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

That doesn't sound good

PM11:25am

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Well, it's tricky to pick much out. It's a trend day.

BE11:25am

There are housbuilders, of course, awaiting the white paper.

BE11:26am

Which is due imminently, though it's been leaked comprehensively.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Try the BBC for a one-stop-shop on the proposals.

BE11:27am

Mr Javid will set out the details of the housing White Paper in a statement to MPs with measures are expected to include:
Forcing councils to produce an up-to-date plan for housing demand
Expecting developers to avoid "low density" housing where land availability is short
Reducing the time allowed between planning permission and the start of building from three to two years
Using a £3bn fund to help smaller building firms challenge major developers, including support for off-site construction, where parts of buildings are assembled in a factory
A "lifetime ISA" to help first-time buyers save for a deposit
Maintaining protection for the green belt, which can only be built on "in exceptional circumstances"

BE11:27am

http://www.bbc.co....-politics-38884601

11:27 am
BE11:27am

What does this mean for the housebuilders? Nearly nothing, of course.

BE11:27am

Here's Jefferies to say, "meh."

BE11:27am

If the BBC is correctly informed, our view is that the White paper has one positive, one re-announcement and one area of concern.
Help to Buy ISA tweaked and now includes access to stocks and shares - our view, every little helps.
One re-announcement: the £3bn fund to help smaller builders and encourage more offsite construction - our view, an increase would be more helpful than a restatement.
One area of concern: expecting developers to avoid 'low density' housing where land availability is short - our view, housebuilders should prioritise building the homes people want to live in rather than merely the number of homes that councils want them to supply.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And here's Shore to say, "meh."

BE11:28am

Finally expected at lunchtime but judging by the leaks and pre-briefings it risks being a damp squib. There looks to be a lot of talk about consultation and creation on new powers (especially for local authorities) but this risk being more talk than action. Also, the targets look under-ambitious (only 25,000 new homes target from SMEs over 3 years for example) and there is also a lot of raking over of old coals with previously announced funding that already previously announced. Starter Homes looks to be back on the agenda but run by councils rather than the builders. Land bank taxes or ‘use or lose’ provisions are to be imposed. Innovation for alternative construction is to be encouraged, possibly even subsidised. The rental sector is to get a material boost but at the largescale, institutional end with nothing likely for small landlords. Green Belt land looks unlikely to be released for development. The rules ‘forcing’ councils to provide more land is also not new but just the existing NPPF re-presented. Lifetime ISA is also not new.
It is still likely that the White Paper will make life less easy for the larger house builders but the proposals we have seen do look a little anaemic.

BE11:28am

You get the idea.

BE11:34am

Conclusion: H1 trading update suggests that trading is in line with our expectations at the half year and on track to deliver our expectations for the full year. We are not changing our estimates. The group remains 'mindful' of the uncertainty regarding the UK economic outlook. However, in our view, today's statement is a picture of inner calm: the strategy is working, the underlying market is supportive and we suspect that today's White Paper will do little to upset the current balance of mindfulness over matter.
Detail: Volumes up 6.5% - guidance for full year +5% (Jef +6%), ASP £256,000, FY guidance £260,000 (Jef £260,000), H1 margin expected to be around 22%, remaining at a similar level for the full year (Jef 21.9%). At 2516p, Bellway trades on a CY17 P/B of 1.35x (sector 1.48x) and offers a yield of 4.3% (sector 5.3%).

BE11:35am

And, Deutsche.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Bellway’s brief trading statement yet again provided a steady message and bringing our forecasts in line with unchanged company guidance has driven 4.5% upside to our PBT ests. With an ambitious growth strategy which should allow volume capture relative to large cap peers combined with conservative management guidance with strong build expertise, we see Bellway as perhaps one of the lower risk growth stories in the sector. However while the stock appears inexpensive at 1.3x 2018 P/NTAV, we continue to see better value growth stories elsewhere. HOLD.

BE11:38am

Bit of laundry sellside?

PM11:38am

11:38 am
BE11:38am

RBC positive on the ever-exciting Berendsen

BE11:39am

Which I still have to stop myself calling The Davis Service Group, which is probably as sign I've done this too long.

BE11:39am

Rebrand was ............. 2011, was it?

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Anyway, RBC's a value call. UK's derated to the point that it's free.

BE11:40am

Whilst there are risks around the UK turnaround and execution of the CEO's strategy, we believe Berendsen is fundamentally a good business and the valuation now discounts these downside risks. We believe the UK is in the price for nothing and the dividend and balance sheet are supportive. We move to Outperform, 950p target.

BE11:40am

UK in the price for nothing - If we look at the price that Rentokil sold its workwear and hygiene business for (15.5x EBITA) or even the Johnson Service Group current multiple (13.0x EBITA), then we can make an argument that the UK business is currently in the price for nothing, even if we factor in additional restructuring costs. We also believe in a consolidating market, the Berendsen valuation is now looking potentially attractive, and we would not rule out some left-field big consolidation.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

"Left-field big consolidation" as in .............. ? Rentokil? Hm.

BE11:41am

UK risks remain - We would note that the UK only now accounts for 15% of forecast group profits and forecasts are now very conservative - eg, we forecast only £6m UK flat-linen profits in 2017E - another leg down from £10m in 16E. We believe the UK operational issues will take time to resolve and that the solution will require plant investment. There is some risk of further disruption and customer service issues, and management has to be careful not to destroy the strong local relationships by making too much change too quickly. We expect detailed turnaround plans at FY results on 3 March. However, the group continues to have strong market positions in what is a capital-intensive business, where scale matters and improvements should hence be achievable over time.

BE11:41am

Europe looks in good shape - We don't believe the European business has been impacted by under-investment issues and expect continued good momentum. This is positive for mix, given margins are significantly higher than in the UK (20% vs 7%). The overall outlook looks positive given relatively robust GDP and potential for further outsourcing. Market positions are strong in Scandinavia and Benelux, and in Germany growth should remain strong as Berendsen takes share from smaller players, with the potential to further consolidate the market. It may also benefit from some fallout from the Rentokil/Haniel link-up.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Forecasts - We reduced EPS forecasts in Jan to reflect the UK issues. We expect a broadly flat underlying profit picture with Europe offsetting the UK and forex benefit meaning we still expect EPS growth in 2017.
Balance sheet and dividend yield supportive - Gearing remains conservative with net debt to EBITDA of c.1.2x at Y/E - this provides options for investments and bolt-on M&A. The dividend yield of 4.0% is now looking supportive, given it is covered 2.0x by EPS and 1.4x by cashflow, even post additional UK capex.

PM11:41am

BE11:45am

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Here's Goodbody.

BE11:47am

DCC issued a Q3 IMS this morning in which the focus of attention will be on the acquisition of Esso’s retail franchise in Norway. Comprising 142 company-operated sites (127 retail service stations and 15 unmanned stations) selling c.600m litres of fuel annually, the network is the third largest in Norway. DCC is guiding a 15% return on the first full year of ownership. Total consideration amounts to £235m, which adds to the £220m recorded in FY17 to date.
With respect to trading activity in Q3, the statement points to an operating profit outcome for the full year “significantly ahead of the prior year and in line with current market consensus”. As expected, Energy (c.70% of Group EBITA) would appear to be the primary driver of growth, aided by an easier comparison relative to milder temperatures in 2016 and the benefit of prior acquisitions.
Energy aside, commentary would suggest that all of the other three divisions - Healthcare, Technology and Environmental – have performed well, with Technology and Environment singled out as delivering strong performances.

BE11:47am

With respect to FY17, given a current EBITA forecast of £355.4m (+18% YoY), relative to an estimated market consensus operating profit of c.£358m, any adjustments to our estimates, are likely to be limited. Beyond that, the acquisition of Esso Retail Norway will clearly provide an uplift to FY18. Guidance suggests deal closure in Q4 2017 with the return by our estimate suggesting a full year contribution of c.£35m. Assuming closure September 2017 and a tax rate in Norway of 25% we estimate a c.4.5% uplift to FY18 earnings.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

......... When one activity provides 70% of group Ebitda, I think it's fair enough to say that's what the company does.

BE11:48am

So, DCC is the petrol station services company, just like Apple is the iPhone maker.

BE11:48am

Come at me, Feltcollaredsource.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Jefferies as well, just for completeness.

BE11:49am

DCC 3Q17 operating profit ‘strongly ahead’ Y/Y with growth across all divisions. £235m Esso Norway retail petrol station network acquisition gives 8% FY19 upgrade (first full year). Post 12% underperformance in past six months (DCC -6% vs. FTSE 100 +6%), with reassurance on FY17 trading and financial flexibility for further accretive M&A: Trading on 20x CY17 PE for 13% FY16-19 EPS CAGR: Reaffirm Buy with increased 7500p PT.
Positive 3Q17 Update: Following 33% DCC 1H17 profit growth (reported in Nov 2016), 3Q17 DCC operating profit ‘strongly ahead’ Y/Y, in-line with expectations, with growth across all divisions. We retain unchanged FY17 estimates: £360m EBIT/298.7p EPS.
3Q17 Divisional Highlights: Energy (71% EBIT) ‘Very strong’ LPG organic volume growth, with Retail & Fuelcard and Oil organic volume growth. Stable heating-related volumes Y/Y, with mild UK weather offset by colder mainland Europe weather. Healthcare (13% EBIT) Continued organic Health & Beauty growth with, as previously flagged, DCC Vital pharma products impacted by FX. Technology (11% EBIT) strongly ahead Y/Y; boosted by CUC acquisition (France) and UK/Irish organic growth. Environmental (5% EBIT) Further UK/Irish profit growth.
£235m Esso Norway Acquisition: DCC acquiring Esso Norway retail petrol station network for NOK 2.43 billion (£235m). This c600m litre pa network comprises: 1) National network of 142 Esso company-operated sites (127 retail service stations/15 unmanned) with 2) Contract to supply additional 108 Esso-branded dealer owned sites. The acquisition has considerable asset backing, as 110 of the 142 Esso company-operated sites are freehold. Esso acquisition is due to complete 4Q CY17; with DCC confident of 15% ROCE. 2%/8% FY18/FY19 Upgrades: Prudently; Jeff model end Dec 2017 Esso completion, giving 2% FY18 PBT/EPS upgrade to £364.4m PBT/331.9p EPS and 8% FY19 upgrade (first full year of inclusion) to £411.8m PBT & 371.0p EPS.

undefined
11:50 am
BE11:50am

While cutting and pasting, big Deutsche note out on the midcap oilers.

BE11:50am

Positive on Cairn, negative on Premier.

BE11:50am

Second call's probably the more interesting one. Talking about a Solan reserve write-down

11:50 am
Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 81.00, down 3.75 (-4.42%), High: 83.50, Low: 79.00, Volume: 7.11m
BE11:51am

So ............

BE11:51am

Our Buy case for Premier has been based on positive tailwinds coming from bringing Solan onstream and completing its refinancing. It's been a volatile 6M, but the catalysts are in and we are somewhat underwhelmed. As outlined in our sector report on field performance, Solan has materially underperformed market expectations and we expect a c.20% write down of reserves at FY16 results next month. The refinancing also came at a cost, with tradable warrants exercisable at a deep discount likely to act as a drag on near-term momentum.
The stock is trading at ~0.8x P/NAV, in line with its peers, but with the highest sensitivity to oil prices in our coverage. Downgrade to Hold.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The upshot of their work is that Solan's not very good.

BE11:52am

As outlined in our sector report on field performance, we expect the reservoir underperformance issues on the Solan field to lead to a c.20% decline in the reported 2P reserves. Premier loses out on $200m of cash flow over 2016-18 vs pre-production guidance, and if these production volumes can’t be recovered then the NPV of this loss is estimated at almost c.$400m (50p/sh) over field life. We think the Solan development will require additional capex, either through a sidetrack of the water injection well or fracking of the existing well bore, in order to recover the majority of these lost reserves. The forecast low $10/b operating costs are also likely to be materially impacted by the loss of production volumes, and could lead to early abandonment of the facility if no action is taken to boost throughput with near-field tie-back opportunities.

BE11:52am

Which is against the backdrop of the refi, of course, which remains a work in progress.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

While the refinancing is well on the way towards completion in 1H17, the restrictions on Premier’s cash flow are unlikely to be tested in the next 12M. In any event, the Solan production downgrade has caused the group’s 2017 breakeven price to rise from $45/b to $50/b Brent, meaning there is little free cash flow until the Catcher field comes onstream. We like the Catcher field and the potential of its reservoir to outperform market expectations, but would rather play this potential upside through Cairn Energy.

BE11:52am

......... And in terms of that Cairn switch advice .....

BE11:53am

Following a review of Cairn’s development portfolio, we upgrade the stock to Buy (from Hold) on its potential to outperform market expectations. We see upside potential on Kraken, and are positive on the Catcher development, where the wells have so far responded well to water injection testing. We also think that Cairn can de-risk its Senegal SNE discovery through well interference testing in the Summer. Taken together with a robust balance sheet and an option on the Cairn India tax arbitration, we think Cairn offers investors several potential catalysts for valuation growth this year. Trading at 0.71x P/NAV, a c.20% discount to the European E&P sector, we upgrade to Buy.

Here's new figures from Nomus.

BE11:58am

DX's trading update indicates that its Courier, Secure and Freight revenues are behind management's expectations. Though DX has secured new Logistics business it is at a lower margin compared to the shared network activities, diluting the overall margin mix. Additionally, dislocation at one site during network integration has caused additional costs. We have cut our EBITDA forecasts for FY17 to £8.7m (from £17.8m) and FY18 to £10.4m (from £18.8m) and EPS to 1.0p (from 4.7p) and 1.8p (from 5.2p).

BE11:59am

In the November Trading Update management indicated that trading conditions had remained challenging; market pricing was competitive and driver costs were an ongoing challenge. The revenue wins were more skewed to lower-margin Logistics contracts. We believe that these themes have continued. Courier and Freight growth rates have slowed from last year and we believe that DX Secure volumes are down year-on-year. Owing to the operational gearing of these activities that use a fixed cost network, the negative impact on the EBITDA margin has been significant. We believe that the volume decline in the Document Exchange has been in line with our expectations at c.-10%.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

(@Lefevre: I'd be more open to the labour-shortage argument if there was any period, or even any geography, where people didn't discover that newbuild fitout quality tends to be crap.)

BE12:00pm

Over the last 2-3 years, we believe that the OneDX depot
rationalisation process has proceeded relatively smoothly. However, during the period under review, five sites were integrated into one, and there were issues at one of the original sites which required additional temporary labour costs.

BE12:01pm

Management expects FY17 results to be significantly below
current market expectations, and will not pay a dividend for the foreseeable future. Though the FY17 revenue out-turn is still expected to be close to our original forecast, the unfavourable margin mix means we now forecast an EBITDA margin of 3% vs. 6% previously. We expect the FY17 EBITDA split to be c.£3.5m in H1 and c.£5m in H2. We believe that cost savings make modest EBITDA progress in FY18 possible, subject to the rate of volume decline in the Document Exchange offset by new revenue streams. We believe that December net debt (the seasonal high point) was c.£20m, and forecast this to reduce to c.£15m in June (1.7x net debt/EBITDA vs. bank covenant of 2x).
